title: Spanish dictator Franco's remains exhumed from state mausoleum
text:
Spanish officials have begun the process of exhuming the remains of Spanish dictator General Francisco Franco from his tomb in a gigantic Catholic basilica, which are to be reinterred in a municipal cemetery outside Madrid.

The exhumation marks the fulfilment of a key policy pledge by Socialist Prime Minister, Pedro Sánchez, following a legal battle against a move the Spanish government said was necessary to “dignify democracy” 45 years after Franco’s death.

“It’s the victory of Spanish democracy,” said Mr Sánchez at a party rally on Wednesday night ahead of elections called for November 10, although opponents accuse the Socialist government of electioneering with Franco's mortal remains.

Franco ruled Spain between 1939 and 1975, after he and other officers led a military insurrection against the Spanish democratic government in 1936, a move that started a three-year civil war that killed 500,000.

His authoritarian rule, along with a profoundly conservative Catholic Church, ensured that Spain remained virtually isolated from political, industrial and cultural developments in Europe for nearly four decades.
